S3.SS3.tab1.table:
The SecAgg Protocol integrated with XNoise
• Setup: – All parties are given the current round index r𝑟r, the security parameter η𝜂\eta, the number of users |U|𝑈\lvert U\rvert and a threshold for SecAgg t𝑡t, honestly generated p​p←KA.gen​(η)←𝑝𝑝KA.gen𝜂pp\leftarrow\textrm{{KA.gen}}(\eta), parameters m𝑚m and R𝑅R such that ℤRmsubscriptsuperscriptℤ𝑚𝑅\mathbb{Z}^{m}_{R} is the space from which inputs are sampled, and a field 𝔽𝔽\mathbb{F} to be used for secret sharing and noise samping, a noise distribution χ𝜒\chi, the target central noise level σ∗2superscriptsubscript𝜎2\sigma_{*}^{2}, a dropout tolerance T𝑇T and a collusion tolerance TCsubscript𝑇𝐶T_{C} for XNoise. All users also have a private authenticated channel with the server. User u{
  • –

    Have an input vector Δu, noises ∼gu,0nu,0χ(⋅σ∗2|U|t-tTC), ∼gu,knu,kχ(⋅σ∗2(+-|U|k1)(-|U|k)t-tTC) (∈k[1,T]) where ←gu,kF for all k.

  • –

    Add to Δu a series of noises and produce ~Δu: =~Δu+Δu∑0≤k≤Tnu,k.

  • –

    [Receive signing key dSKu from the trusted third party, together with verification keys dPKv bound to each identity v.]

\textrm{{User} \ }u\left\{\begin{minipage}[c]{390.25534pt} \begin{itemize}\par\itemize@item@[--] {\color[rgb]{0.58,0.06,0}\definecolor[named]{pgfstrokecolor}{rgb}{0.58,0.06,0}\text@underline{Have an input vector $\bm{\Delta}_{u}$, noises $\bm{n}_{u,0}\stackrel{{\scriptstyle g_{u,0}}}{{\sim}}\chi\left(\frac{\sigma_{*}^{2}}{\lvert U\rvert}\cdot\frac{t}{t-T_{C}}\right)$, $\bm{n}_{u,k}\stackrel{{\scriptstyle g_{u,k}}}{{\sim}}\chi\left(\frac{\sigma_{*}^{2}}{(\lvert U\rvert-k+1)(\lvert U\rvert-k)}\cdot\frac{t}{t-T_{C}}\right)$ ($k\in[1,T]$) where $g_{u,k}\leftarrow\mathbb{F}$ for all $k$.}} \par\itemize@item@[--] {\color[rgb]{0.58,0.06,0}\definecolor[named]{pgfstrokecolor}{rgb}{0.58,0.06,0}\text@underline{Add to $\bm{\Delta}_{u}$ a series of noises and produce $\tilde{\bm{\Delta}}_{u}$: $\tilde{\bm{\Delta}}_{u}=\bm{\Delta}_{u}+\sum_{0\leq k\leq T}\bm{n}_{u,k}$.}} \par\itemize@item@[--] {[\lx@texthl@color{Receive signing key $d^{SK}_{u}$ from the trusted third party, together with verification keys $d^{PK}_{v}$ bound to each identity $v$.}]} \par\end{itemize} \end{minipage}\right. • Stage 0 (AdvertiseKeys):
User u{
  • –

    Generate key pairs ←(cPKu,cSKu)KA.gen(pp), ←(sPKu,sSKu)KA.gen(pp), [and generate ωu←SIG.sign(duSK,∥cuPKsuPK)=1].

  • –

    Send (cuPK∥suPK[∥ωu]) to the server (through the private authenticated channel) and move to next round.

\textrm{{User} \ }u\left\{\begin{minipage}[c]{390.25534pt} \begin{itemize}\par\itemize@item@[--] Generate key pairs \lx@texthl@color{$(c^{PK}_{u},c^{SK}_{u})\leftarrow\textrm{{KA.gen}}(pp)$}, $(s^{PK}_{u},s^{SK}_{u})\leftarrow\textrm{{KA.gen}}(pp)$, {[\lx@texthl@color{and generate $\omega_{u}\leftarrow\textrm{{SIG.sign}}(d_{u}^{SK},c_{u}^{PK}\|s_{u}^{PK})=1$}]}. \par\itemize@item@[--] Send $($\lx@texthl@color{$c_{u}^{PK}$}$\|s_{u}^{PK}${[\lx@texthl@color{$\|\omega_{u}$}]}$)$ to the server (through the private authenticated channel) and move to next round. \par\end{itemize} \end{minipage}\right. Server {
  • –

    Collect at least t messages from individual users in the previous round (denote with U1 this set of users). Otherwise, abort.

  • –

    Broadcast to all users in U1 the list {(v,cvPK,svPK[,ωv]}∈vU1.

\textrm{{Server} \ }\left\{\begin{minipage}[c]{390.25534pt} \begin{itemize}\par\itemize@item@[--] \lx@texthl@color{Collect at least $t$ messages from individual users in the previous round (denote with $U_{1}$ this set of users). Otherwise, abort.} \par\itemize@item@[--] Broadcast to all users in $U_{1}$ the list $\{($\lx@texthl@color{$v,c_{v}^{PK}$}$,s_{v}^{PK}${[\lx@texthl@color{$,\omega_{v}$}]}$\}_{v\in U_{1}}$. \par\end{itemize} \end{minipage}\right. • Stage 1 (ShareKeys):
User u{
  • –

    Receive the list {(v,cvPK,svPK[,ωv]}∈vU1 broadcasted by the server. Assert that >|U1|t, that all the public keys pairs are different, [and that ∈∀vU1, =SIG.ver(dvPK,∥cvPKsvPK,ωv)1].

  • –

    Sample a random element ←buF (to be used as a seed for a PRG).

  • –

    Generate t-out-of-|U1| shares of suSK: ←{(v,su,vSK)}∈vU1SS.share(suSK,t,U1) and of bu: ←{(v,bu,v)}∈vU1SS.share(bu,t,U1).

  • –

    Generate t-out-of-|U1| shares for each of gu,k where >k0: ←{(v,gu,k,v)}∈vU1SS.share(gu,k,t,U1) for =k[1,T].

  • –

    For each other user ∈v∖U1{u}, compute eu,v←AE.enc( KA.agree(cuSK,cvPK),u∥v∥su,vSK∥bu,v∥{gu,k,v}1≤k≤T).

  • –

    If any of the above operations (assertion, signature verification, key agreement, encryption) fails, abort.

  • –

    Send all the ciphertexts eu,v to the server (each implicitly containing addressing information, u, v as metadata).

\textrm{{User} \ }u\left\{\begin{minipage}[c]{390.25534pt} \begin{itemize}\par\itemize@item@[--] Receive the list $\{($\lx@texthl@color{$v,c_{v}^{PK}$}$,s_{v}^{PK}${[\lx@texthl@color{$,\omega_{v}$}]}$\}_{v\in U_{1}}$ broadcasted by the server. \lx@texthl@color{Assert that $\lvert U_{1}\rvert>t$, that all the public keys pairs are different}, {[\lx@texthl@color{and that $\forall v\in U_{1}$, $\textrm{{SIG.ver}}(d_{v}^{PK},c_{v}^{PK}\|s_{v}^{PK},\omega_{v})=1$}]}. \par\itemize@item@[--] Sample a random element $b_{u}\leftarrow\mathbb{F}$ (to be used as a seed for a $\textrm{{PRG}}$). \par\itemize@item@[--] Generate $t$-out-of-$\lvert U_{1}\rvert$ shares of $s_{u}^{SK}$: $\{(v,s_{u,v}^{SK})\}_{v\in U_{1}}\leftarrow\textrm{{SS.share}}(s_{u}^{SK},t,U_{1})$ and of $b_{u}$: $\{(v,b_{u,v})\}_{v\in U_{1}}\leftarrow\textrm{{SS.share}}(b_{u},t,U_{1})$. \par\itemize@item@[--] {\color[rgb]{0.58,0.06,0}\definecolor[named]{pgfstrokecolor}{rgb}{0.58,0.06,0}\text@underline{Generate $t$-out-of-$\lvert U_{1}\rvert$ shares for each of $g_{u,k}$ where $k>0$: $\{(v,g_{u,k,v})\}_{v\in U_{1}}\leftarrow\textrm{{SS.share}}(g_{u,k},t,U_{1})$ for $k=[1,T]$.}} \par\itemize@item@[--]For each other user $v\in U_{1}\setminus\{u\}$, compute \lx@texthl@color{$e_{u,v}\leftarrow\textrm{{AE.enc}}($ $\textrm{{KA.agree}}(c_{u}^{SK},c_{v}^{PK})$}$,u\|v\|s_{u,v}^{SK}\|b_{u,v}${\color[rgb]{0.58,0.06,0}\definecolor[named]{pgfstrokecolor}{rgb}{0.58,0.06,0}\text@underline{$\|\{g_{u,k,v}\}_{1\leq k\leq T}$}}$)$. \par\itemize@item@[--] \lx@texthl@color{If any of the above operations (assertion, signature verification, key agreement, encryption) fails, abort.} \par\itemize@item@[--] \lx@texthl@color{Send all the ciphertexts $e_{u,v}$ to the server (each implicitly containing addressing information, $u$, $v$ as metadata)}. \par\end{itemize} \end{minipage}\right. Server {
  • –

    Collect lists of ciphertexts from at least t users (denote with ⊆U2U1 this set of users).

  • –

    Sends to each user ∈uU2 all ciphertexts encrypted for it: {eu,v}∈vU2.

\textrm{{Server} \ }\left\{\begin{minipage}[c]{390.25534pt} \begin{itemize}\par\itemize@item@[--] \lx@texthl@color{Collect lists of ciphertexts from at least $t$ users (denote with $U_{2}\subseteq U_{1}$ this set of users)}. \par\itemize@item@[--] \lx@texthl@color{Sends to each user $u\in U_{2}$ all ciphertexts encrypted for it: $\{e_{u,v}\}_{v\in U_{2}}$}. \par\end{itemize} \end{minipage}\right. • Stage 2 (MaskedInputCollection):
User u{
  • –

    Receive (and store) from the server the list of ciphertexts {eu,v}∈vU2 (and infer the set U2). If the list is of size <t, abort.

  • –

    For each other user ∈v∖U2{u}, compute ←su,vKA.agree(suSK,svPK) and expand this value using a PRG into a random vector =pu,v⋅γu,vPRG(su,v), where =γu,v1 when >uv, and =γu,v-1 when <uv (note that +pu,vpv,u=0∀u≠v). Define =pu,u0.

  • –

    Compute the user’s own private mask vector =puPRG(bu) and the masked perturbed input ←yu+~Δupu∑∈vU2pu,v(modR).

  • –

    If any of the above operations (key agreement, PRG) fails, abort. Otherwise, send yu to the server and move to the next round.

\textrm{{User} \ }u\left\{\begin{minipage}[c]{390.25534pt} \begin{itemize}\par\itemize@item@[--] \lx@texthl@color{Receive (and store) from the server the list of ciphertexts $\{e_{u,v}\}_{v\in U_{2}}$ (and infer the set $U_{2}$). If the list is of size $<t$, abort.} \par\itemize@item@[--] For each other user $v\in U_{2}\setminus\{u\}$, compute $s_{u,v}\leftarrow\textrm{{KA.agree}}(s_{u}^{SK},s_{v}^{PK})$ and expand this value using a $\mathrm{\mathbf{PRG}}$ into a random vector $\bm{p}_{u,v}=\gamma_{u,v}\cdot\textrm{{PRG}}(s_{u,v})$, where $\gamma_{u,v}=1$ when $u>v$, and $\gamma_{u,v}=-1$ when $u<v$ (note that $\bm{p}_{u,v}+\bm{p}_{v,u}=0\forall u\neq v$). Define $\bm{p}_{u,u}=0$. \par\itemize@item@[--] Compute the user's own private mask vector $\bm{p}_{u}=\textrm{{PRG}}(b_{u})$ and the masked perturbed input $\bm{y}_{u}\leftarrow\tilde{\bm{\Delta}}_{u}+\bm{p}_{u}+\sum_{v\in U_{2}}\bm{p}_{u,v}\pmod{R}$. \par\itemize@item@[--] If any of the above operations (key agreement, PRG) fails, abort. Otherwise, send $\bm{y}_{u}$ to the server and move to the next round. \par\end{itemize} \end{minipage}\right. Server: Collect 𝒚usubscript𝒚𝑢\bm{y}_{u} from at least t𝑡t users (denote with U3⊆U2subscript𝑈3subscript𝑈2U_{3}\subseteq U_{2} this set of users). Send to each user in U3subscript𝑈3U_{3} the list U3subscript𝑈3U_{3}. • [Stage 3 (ConsistencyCheck)]:
User u𝑢u: [Receive from the server a list U3⊆U2subscript𝑈3subscript𝑈2U_{3}\subseteq U_{2} containing at least t𝑡t users (u𝑢u included). Abort if |U3|<tsubscript𝑈3𝑡\lvert U_{3}\rvert<t. Send to the server ωu′←SIG.sign(duS​K,\omega^{\prime}_{u}\leftarrow\textrm{{SIG.sign}}(d_{u}^{SK},r∥r\|U3)U_{3}).]
Server: [Collect ωu′subscriptsuperscript𝜔′𝑢\omega^{\prime}_{u} from at least t𝑡t users (denote with U4⊆U3subscript𝑈4subscript𝑈3U_{4}\subseteq U_{3} this set of users). Send to each user in U4subscript𝑈4U_{4} the set {v,ωv′}v∈U4subscript𝑣subscriptsuperscript𝜔′𝑣𝑣subscript𝑈4\{v,\omega^{\prime}_{v}\}_{v\in U_{4}}.] • Stage 4 (Unmasking):
User u{
  • –

    Receive from the server a list {v[,ω′v]}∈vU4. Verify that ⊆U4U3, that ≥|U4|t [, that SIG.ver(dPKv,r∥U3,ω′v)=1 for all ∈vU4, (otherwise abort).]

  • –

    For each other user v∈U2⊆{u}, decrypt the ciphertext ∥v′‖u′‖sv,uSKbv,u∥{gv,k,u}1≤k≤T←AE.dec(KA.agree(cuSK,cvPK),ev,u) received in the MaskedInputCollection round and assert that u=∧u′v=v′.

  • –

    If any of the decryption operations fail (in particular, the ciphertext does not correctly authenticate), abort.

  • –

    Send a list of shares to the server: sv,uSK for users ∈v∖U2U3 and bv,u in ∈vU3; and a list of seeds gu,k for +|∖UU3|1≤k≤T.

\textrm{{User} \ }u\left\{\begin{minipage}[c]{390.25534pt} \begin{itemize}\par\itemize@item@[--] \lx@texthl@color{Receive from the server a list $\{v$}{[\lx@texthl@color{$,\omega^{\prime}_{v}$}]}\lx@texthl@color{$\}_{v\in U_{4}}$. Verify that $U_{4}\subseteq U_{3}$, that $\lvert U_{4}\rvert\geq t$} {[\lx@texthl@color{, that $\textrm{{SIG.ver}}(d^{PK}_{v},$}$r\|$\lx@texthl@color{$U_{3},\omega^{\prime}_{v})=1$ for all $v\in U_{4}$, (otherwise abort).}]} \par\itemize@item@[--] For each other user $v\in U_{2}\subseteq\{u\}$, decrypt the ciphertext $v^{\prime}\|u^{\prime}\|s_{v,u}^{SK}\|b_{v,u}${\color[rgb]{0.58,0.06,0}\definecolor[named]{pgfstrokecolor}{rgb}{0.58,0.06,0}\text@underline{$\|\{g_{v,k,u}\}_{1\leq k\leq T}$}}$\leftarrow\textrm{{AE.dec}}($\lx@texthl@color{$\textrm{{KA.agree}}(c_{u}^{SK},c_{v}^{PK}),e_{v,u})$} received in the {MaskedInputCollection} round and \lx@texthl@color{assert that $u=u^{\prime}\wedge v=v^{\prime}$}. \par\itemize@item@[--] \lx@texthl@color{If any of the decryption operations fail (in particular, the ciphertext does not correctly authenticate), abort.} \par\itemize@item@[--] Send a list of shares to the server: $s_{v,u}^{SK}$ for users $v\in U_{2}\setminus U_{3}$ and $b_{v,u}$ in $v\in U_{3}$; {\color[rgb]{0.58,0.06,0}\definecolor[named]{pgfstrokecolor}{rgb}{0.58,0.06,0}\text@underline{and a list of seeds $g_{u,k}$ for $\lvert U\setminus U_{3}\rvert+1\leq k\leq T$}}. \par\end{itemize} \end{minipage}\right. Server {
  • –

    Collect responses from at least t users (denote with ⊆U5U4 this set of users).

  • –

    For each user ∈u∖U2U3, reconstruct ←suSKSS.recon({su,vSK}∈vU5,t) and use it (with the public keys received in the AdvertiseKeys round) to recompute pu,v for all ∈vU3 using the PRG. For each user ∈uU3, reconstruct ←buSS.recon({bu,v}∈vU5,t) to recompute pu using the PRG.

  • –

    Compute =z∑∈uU3~Δu as =∑∈uU3~Δu+-∑∈uU3yu∑∈uU3pu∑∈uU3,∈v∖U2U3pv,u.

  • –

    Sends to each user ∈uU5 the set U5, if ≠∖U3U5∅.

\textrm{{Server} \ }\left\{\begin{minipage}[c]{390.25534pt} \begin{itemize}\par\itemize@item@[--] \lx@texthl@color{Collect responses from at least $t$ users (denote with $U_{5}\subseteq U_{4}$ this set of users).} \par\itemize@item@[--] For each user $u\in U_{2}\setminus U_{3}$, reconstruct $s_{u}^{SK}\leftarrow\textrm{{SS.recon}}(\{s_{u,v}^{SK}\}_{v\in U_{5}},t)$ and use it (with the public keys received in the {AdvertiseKeys} round) to recompute $\bm{p}_{u,v}$ for all $v\in U_{3}$ using the PRG. For each user $u\in U_{3}$, reconstruct $b_{u}\leftarrow\textrm{{SS.recon}}(\{b_{u,v}\}_{v\in U_{5}},t)$ to recompute $\bm{p}_{u}$ using the PRG. \par\itemize@item@[--] Compute $\bm{z}=\sum_{u\in U_{3}}\tilde{\bm{\Delta}}_{u}$ as $\sum_{u\in U_{3}}\tilde{\bm{\Delta}}_{u}=\sum_{u\in U_{3}}\bm{y_{u}}-\sum_{u\in U_{3}}\bm{p_{u}}+\sum_{u\in U_{3},v\in U_{2}\setminus U_{3}}\bm{p}_{v,u}$. \par\itemize@item@[--] {\color[rgb]{0.58,0.06,0}\definecolor[named]{pgfstrokecolor}{rgb}{0.58,0.06,0}\text@underline{Sends to each user $u\in U_{5}$ the set $U_{5}$, if $U_{3}\setminus U_{5}\neq\emptyset$.}} \par\end{itemize} \end{minipage}\right. • Stage 5 (ExcessiveNoiseRemoval):
User u{
  • –

    Receive from the server the set U5. Verify that ⊆U5U4 and that ≥U5t (otherwise abort).

  • –

    Send a list of shares to the server, which consists of gv,k,u for users ∈v∖U3U5 and +|∖UU3|1≤k≤T.

\textrm{{User} \ }u\left\{\begin{minipage}[c]{390.25534pt} \begin{itemize}\par\itemize@item@[--] {\color[rgb]{0.58,0.06,0}\definecolor[named]{pgfstrokecolor}{rgb}{0.58,0.06,0}\text@underline{Receive from the server the set $U_{5}$. Verify that $U_{5}\subseteq U_{4}$ and that $U_{5}\geq t$ (otherwise abort).}} \par\itemize@item@[--] {\color[rgb]{0.58,0.06,0}\definecolor[named]{pgfstrokecolor}{rgb}{0.58,0.06,0}\text@underline{Send a list of shares to the server, which consists of $g_{v,k,u}$ for users $v\in U_{3}\setminus U_{5}$ and $\lvert U\setminus U_{3}\rvert+1\leq k\leq T$.}} \par\end{itemize} \end{minipage}\right. Server { – Collect responses from at least t users (denote with ⊆U6U5 this set of users). – For each user ∈u∖U3U5, reconstruct ←gu,kSS.recon({gu,k,v}∈vU6,t) for +|∖UU3|1≤k≤T. – Generate random noises ∼gu,knu,kχ(⋅σ∗2(+-|U|k1)(-|U|k)t-tTC) for ∈uU3 and +|∖UU3|1≤k≤T and subtracts them from z. \textrm{{Server} \ }\left\{\begin{minipage}[c]{390.25534pt} \begin{itemize}\par\itemize@item@[--] {\color[rgb]{0.58,0.06,0}\definecolor[named]{pgfstrokecolor}{rgb}{0.58,0.06,0}\text@underline{Collect responses from at least $t$ users (denote with $U_{6}\subseteq U_{5}$ this set of users).}} \par\itemize@item@[--] {\color[rgb]{0.58,0.06,0}\definecolor[named]{pgfstrokecolor}{rgb}{0.58,0.06,0}\text@underline{For each user $u\in U_{3}\setminus U_{5}$, reconstruct $g_{u,k}\leftarrow\textrm{{SS.recon}}(\{g_{u,k,v}\}_{v\in U_{6}},t)$ for $\lvert U\setminus U_{3}\rvert+1\leq k\leq T$.}} \par\itemize@item@[--] {\color[rgb]{0.58,0.06,0}\definecolor[named]{pgfstrokecolor}{rgb}{0.58,0.06,0}\text@underline{Generate random noises $\bm{n}_{u,k}\stackrel{{\scriptstyle g_{u,k}}}{{\sim}}\chi\left(\frac{\sigma_{*}^{2}}{(\lvert U\rvert-k+1)(\lvert U\rvert-k)}\cdot\frac{t}{t-T_{C}}\right)$ for $u\in U_{3}$ and $\lvert U\setminus U_{3}\rvert+1\leq k\leq T$ and subtracts them from $\bm{z}$.}} \par\end{itemize} \end{minipage}\right.
Figure 5. Detailed description of the SecAgg protocol (Bonawitz et al., 2017a) integrated with XNoise (section 3.2). [Italicized parts inside square brackets are required to guarantee security in the malicious threat model.] Red, underlined parts are specific for XNoise. Green, highlighted parts are secure results of SecAgg reused by XNoise. The symbol ∥∥\| denotes concatenation.

references:
We present Dordis, a distributed differentially private
FL framework that is highly efficient and resilient to client dropout.
Specifically, we develop a novel ‘add-then-remove’ scheme that enforces a required noise level precisely in each training round, even if some sampled clients drop out.
This ensures that the privacy budget is utilized prudently, despite unpredictable client dynamics.
To boost performance, Dordis operates as a distributed parallel architecture via encapsulating the communication and computation operations into stages.
It automatically divides the global model aggregation into several chunk-aggregation tasks and pipelines them for optimal speedup.
Large-scale deployment evaluations demonstrate that Dordis efficiently handles client dropout in various realistic FL scenarios, achieving the optimal privacy-utility tradeoff and accelerating training by up to 2.4×\times compared to existing solutions.

Abstracting Workflow for Generality.   Unlike traditional ML workflows, which involve a computation graph of neural network with general consensus established on their representation (Abadi et al., 2016a; Jia et al., 2019), secure aggregation protocols combine both computation and communication, with no standardized approach.
Nonetheless, we notice that secure aggregation protocols are often designed as multi-round server-client interactions.
We thus propose to represent the workflow of a secure aggregation protocol as a sequence of ‘round-trip steps’, each of which starts with the server’s request for some data and ends with the related clients’ responses.
Furthermore, we associate each step with its dominant system resource and group consecutive steps that use the same resource into a stage which corresponds to the minimum scheduling unit in pipelining.
For example, Table 1 illustrates our representation of a distributed DP protocol using SecAgg (Bonawitz et al., 2017a), where all 11 steps are grouped into 5 stages.

Our noise enforcement scheme, XNoise, ensures that the target privacy level is consistently attained, even when client dropout occurs, without impairing model utility (section 6.2).
The runtime overhead is deemed acceptable even without pipeline acceleration, and the network overhead remains constant despite the model’s expanding size (section 6.3).

We also report the final model accuracy in Table 2.
Compared to Orig, which fails to achieve the target privacy in the presence
of client dropout, our XNoise converges at the same speed
(as exemplified by the learning curves in Figure 9 where the per-round dropout rate is 20%)
and induces no more than 0.9% accuracy loss as it uses the minimum noise required to maintain the desired level of privacy.
It should be noted that the accuracies obtained with Dordis are similar to those in other FL studies that use distributed DP (Kairouz et al., 2021a; Agarwal et al., 2021; Stevens et al., 2022).
This is because FL clients have limited and non-IID data, and model updates are discretized for secure aggregation.
Additionally, in some cases, XNoise achieves higher accuracy than Orig, even though the latter uses less noise.
This is because the stochasticity introduced by slight additional random noise can act as a regularizer to reduce overfitting (Neelakantan et al., 2015; Liu et al., 2020).

XNoise Induces Acceptable Overhead in Time.  
Figure 10 shows the average round time, broken down into two components: ‘agg’, related to distributed DP operations, and ‘other’, related to remaining workflow operations such as model training.
In a plain execution without pipeline acceleration (yellow bars for Orig and XNoise in Figure 10(a) to 10(d) and Figure 10(i) to 10(l)), XNoise extends the round time
by up to 34% given no dropout, and by up to 19%, 13%, and 12% when the per-round dropout rate is 10%, 20%, and 30%, respectively.
This implies a negative relationship between the time cost and dropout severity, as the more clients that drop out, the less noise the server needs to remove in XNoise (Definition 2).
Such a relationship also implies an acceptable overhead in practice, as Dordis targets scenarios with client dropout.
Moreover, the overhead can be further reduced by Dordis’s pipeline acceleration (section 6.4).

XNoise’s Network Overhead is Invariant of Model Size.  
The noise decomposition in XNoise allows for the transmission of noise seeds (section 3.1).
To examine its practical advantage over ‘rebasing’, we benchmark their additional network footprint induced to a surviving client compared to Orig.
As specified in real deployments, the size of a model weight, noise seed, Shamir share of seed, ciphertext of a share (the latter three are configured for XNoise only) are set to 2.5, 32, 16, and 120 in bytes, respectively.
As seen in Table 3, as the model size increases, the network overhead of XNoise remains constant and low, while that of ‘rebasing’ grows linearly.
The communication time of ‘rebasing’ can thus be prohibitive when the model is large in size (e.g., ¿500M) and/or the client’s bandwidth is low (e.g., ¡1Mbps).
Additionally, a large overhead makes client failures in the middle of noise removal more likely, which ‘rebasing’ cannot handle without the loss of model utility (section 3.1).

It is important to highlight that the cost of Dordis is dependent on the number of sampled clients rather than the overall population size.
In FL systems, although the population can be extensive, the number of sampled clients is typically restricted to a few hundred (Kairouz et al., 2021b; Bonawitz et al., 2019).
This limitation is due to the fact that involving additional clients beyond a certain threshold only yields marginal benefits in terms of accelerating convergence (McMahan et al., 2017; Wang et al., 2021).
Therefore, the results presented in Table 3 are evaluated from practical settings of sample sizes and are applicable in real-world scenarios.

In this hybrid, SIM has access to all the inputs of honest parties 𝚫U∖Csubscript𝚫𝑈𝐶\bm{\Delta}_{U\setminus C}, and gU∖Csubscript𝑔𝑈𝐶g_{U\setminus C}, and runs the full protocol with MCsubscript𝑀𝐶M_{C}, which includes simulating the random oracle ‘on the fly’ (using a dynamically generated table), the PKI, and the rest of the Setup phase. The view of the adversary here is the same as the previous one.

Support for Diverse Distributed DP Algorithms.  
As outlined in Section 5, Dordis offers developers the capability to implement customized distributed DP algorithms using the provided generic programming interface.
To facilitate this, Table 4 presents the base classes that can be tailored to specific requirements.

The first base class, ProtocolServer, serves as a foundation for implementing various server-side workflows (as exemplified in Table 1).
To streamline the development of computation logic, Dordis supplies established communication primitives based on Socket.IO (pyt, [n. d.])), which developers can employ to handle server-client interactions effectively.
To specify the execution order and resource dependencies of different operations, Dordis further provides the set_graph_dict() method, allowing developers to annotate and aid Dordis in planning an optimized pipeline acceleration (see section 4.2).

Support for Diverse Applications.  
Table 4 also demonstrates that Dordis offers developers the flexibility to extend the aggregation framework to power various privacy-sensitive applications beyond FL. This versatility allows for seamless integration into different use cases.
To achieve this, developers can leverage the AppServer class by overriding the use_output() method, which specifies how the aggregated result is utilized by the server.
Likewise, developers can instantiate their own AppClient and customize its behavior by overriding two methods. Firstly, the prepare_data() method can be modified to define how a client’s data is generated. Secondly, the use_output() method can be configured to determine how the aggregated result is consumed by the client.
We have made Dordis open-source and warmly welcome contributions from the research community to further advance privacy-preserving data analytics research.

C1: Our noise enforcement scheme, XNoise, guarantees the consistent achievement of the desired privacy level, even in the presence of client dropout, while maintaining the model utility.
This claim is supported by the simulation experiment (E1) outlined in section 6.2, with the corresponding results presented in Figure 8, Table 2, and Figure 9.

C2: The XNoise scheme introduces acceptable runtime overhead, with the network overhead being scalable with respect to the model’s expanding size. S
This can be proven by the cluster experiment (E2) described in 6.3 whose results are reported in Figure 10 and Table 3.

S4.T1.caption: Table 1. Abstracting the workflow of dropout-resilient distributed DP into multiple stages for pipelined execution.
S4.T1.table:
Step Operation Stage (Resource)
1 Clients encode updates. 1 (c-comp)
2 Clients generate security keys.
3 Clients establish shared secrets.
4 Clients mask encoded updates.
5 Clients upload masked updates. 2 (comm)
6 Server deals with dropout. 3 (s-comp)
7 Server computes aggregate update.
8 Server updates the global model.
9 Server dispatches the aggregate. 4 (comm)
10 Clients decode the aggregate. 5 (c-comp)
11 Clients use the aggregate.
references:

Furthermore, we associate each step with its dominant system resource and group consecutive steps that use the same resource into a stage which corresponds to the minimum scheduling unit in pipelining.
For example, Table 1 illustrates our representation of a distributed DP protocol using SecAgg (Bonawitz et al., 2017a), where all 11 steps are grouped into 5 stages.

XNoise’s Network Overhead is Invariant of Model Size.  
The noise decomposition in XNoise allows for the transmission of noise seeds (section 3.1).
To examine its practical advantage over ‘rebasing’, we benchmark their additional network footprint induced to a surviving client compared to Orig.
As specified in real deployments, the size of a model weight, noise seed, Shamir share of seed, ciphertext of a share (the latter three are configured for XNoise only) are set to 2.5, 32, 16, and 120 in bytes, respectively.
As seen in Table 3, as the model size increases, the network overhead of XNoise remains constant and low, while that of ‘rebasing’ grows linearly.
The communication time of ‘rebasing’ can thus be prohibitive when the model is large in size (e.g., ¿500M) and/or the client’s bandwidth is low (e.g., ¡1Mbps).
Additionally, a large overhead makes client failures in the middle of noise removal more likely, which ‘rebasing’ cannot handle without the loss of model utility (section 3.1).

It is important to highlight that the cost of Dordis is dependent on the number of sampled clients rather than the overall population size.
In FL systems, although the population can be extensive, the number of sampled clients is typically restricted to a few hundred (Kairouz et al., 2021b; Bonawitz et al., 2019).
This limitation is due to the fact that involving additional clients beyond a certain threshold only yields marginal benefits in terms of accelerating convergence (McMahan et al., 2017; Wang et al., 2021).

A3.T4.caption: Table 4. The programming interface provided for developers to customize their own distributed DP algorithms and applications.
A3.T4.table:
Category Base Class Customization Instruction
Distributed DP ProtocolServer Overwrite set_graph_dict() to specify the distributed DP workflow for pipeline plan generation. Create one method for coordinating each operation, e.g., encode_data() to instruct DP encoding.
ProtocolClient Overwrite set_routine() to specify the handler for each server’s request. Create one method for processing each server’s request, e.g., encode_data() to encode local input on request.
DPHandler Overwrite init_params() to specify how to initialize DP parameters, encode_data() and decode_data() to how to perform DP encoding and decoding given a chunk of input, respectively.
AEHandler, KAHandler, PGHandler, SSHandler Overwrite the respective functionality for necessary security primitives: authenticated encryption, key agreement, pseudorandom generator, and secret sharing.
Application AppServer Overwrite use_output() to specify how the server uses the output of distributed DP.
AppClient Overwrite prepare_data() and use_output() to specify how a client prepares the input and consumes the output of distributed DP, respectively.
references:
Support for Diverse Distributed DP Algorithms.  
As outlined in Section 5, Dordis offers developers the capability to implement customized distributed DP algorithms using the provided generic programming interface.
To facilitate this, Table 4 presents the base classes that can be tailored to specific requirements.

Support for Diverse Applications.  
Table 4 also demonstrates that Dordis offers developers the flexibility to extend the aggregation framework to power various privacy-sensitive applications beyond FL. This versatility allows for seamless integration into different use cases.
To achieve this, developers can leverage the AppServer class by overriding the use_output() method, which specifies how the aggregated result is utilized by the server.
Likewise, developers can instantiate their own AppClient and customize its behavior by overriding two methods. Firstly, the prepare_data() method can be modified to define how a client’s data is generated. Secondly, the use_output() method can be configured to determine how the aggregated result is consumed by the client.
We have made Dordis open-source and warmly welcome contributions from the research community to further advance privacy-preserving data analytics research.
